per_sample.article: Scientists at the Indian Institute of Space Research have successfully tested a new reusable launch vehicle prototype off the coast of Andhra Pradesh. The winged craft, lifted by a solid-fuel booster, climbed to an altitude of 70 kilometers before gliding back to a controlled splashdown in the Bay of Bengal. Engineers say the data gathered from this flight will shape the design of a larger vehicle capable of cutting launch costs by more than 50 percent. The mission, which lasted just under 15 minutes, is seen as a key milestone in India's effort to compete in the global commercial launch market. Officials stressed that at least half a dozen more tests will be needed before a full-scale demonstration, but called the debut "a major step toward low-cost access to space."
per_sample.model_summary: The Indian Institute of Space Research successfully tested a reusable launch vehicle prototype off the coast of Andhra Pradesh, reaching an altitude of 70 kilometers and gliding back to a controlled splashdown in the Bay of Bengal. The mission, which lasted 15 minutes, aims to cut launch costs by more than 50 percent and is seen as a key milestone in India's effort to compete in the global commercial launch market. At least half a dozen more tests are required before a full-scale demonstration can be conducted.
highlights: India tests reusable launch vehicle prototype over Bay of Bengal.
Short suborbital flight gathers data to cut future launch costs.
Officials hail mission as milestone toward low-cost access to space.

per_sample.article: Heavy pre-monsoon showers brought relief to residents across Hyderabad on Tuesday evening after weeks of sweltering heat. The India Meteorological Department recorded over 40 millimeters of rain in less than two hours in several parts of the city, leading to waterlogging on major arterial roads. Traffic police deployed additional personnel at critical junctions as commuters struggled with knee-deep water in low-lying areas. Power distribution companies reported scattered outages but said most were restored within an hour. Weather officials say more thunderstorms are likely over the next three days as a low-pressure system strengthens over the Bay of Bengal.
per_sample.model_summary: Heavy pre-monsoon showers brought relief to residents across Hyderabad on Tuesday evening, with over 40 millimeters of rain recorded in less than two hours in several parts of the city. The downpour led to waterlogging on major arterial roads, prompting traffic police to deploy additional personnel at critical junctions. Power distribution companies reported scattered outages but most were restored within an hour, with weather officials predicting more thunderstorms over the next three days as a low-pressure system strengthens over the Bay of Bengal.
highlights: Pre-monsoon showers cool Hyderabad after prolonged heatwave.
Downpour causes waterlogging and traffic disruptions in low-lying areas.
Meteorological department predicts more thunderstorms in coming days.

per_sample.article: A small rural school in Karnataka has become a national example for integrating technology into primary education. Teachers at the government-run campus in Tumakuru district have converted an unused storeroom into a digital classroom, equipped with second-hand tablets, a low-cost projector and open-source learning software. The project began when a group of alumni working in Bengaluru pooled funds and volunteered to conduct weekend training sessions for staff. Within a year, attendance at the school rose by nearly 20 percent, and test scores in mathematics and science improved across all grades. State officials have since visited the campus and are exploring ways to replicate the model in other districts with limited budgets.

The project, launched by a group of alumni in Bengaluru, has led to a 20% increase in attendance and improved test scores in mathematics and science across all grades. State officials are now exploring ways to replicate the model in other districts with limited budgets.

Alumni-funded project boosts attendance and test scores.
State authorities weigh scaling low-cost model to other districts.

per_sample.article: Global oil prices fell sharply on Thursday after fresh data showed weaker-than-expected manufacturing output in the United States and Europe. Brent crude futures dropped below $80 a barrel for the first time in six months, extending a week-long slide triggered by concerns over slowing demand. Analysts said investors were also reacting to signals from major producers that they might not cut output as aggressively as previously anticipated. Airline and shipping stocks rallied on the news, while energy companies saw their share prices decline. Economists cautioned that the lower prices, while beneficial for consumers, could destabilize budgets in oil-exporting countries already under fiscal pressure.
per_sample.model_summary: Global oil prices fell sharply on Thursday after fresh data showed weaker-than-expected manufacturing output in the United States and Europe, with Brent crude futures dropping below $80 a barrel for the first time in six months. This decline in oil prices is expected to benefit consumers, but could also destabilize budgets in oil-exporting countries.
highlights: Brent crude falls below $80 amid weak manufacturing data.
Investors doubt that major producers will cut output deeply.
Cheaper oil lifts transport stocks but pressures exporters' budgets.

per_sample.article: A new study published in a leading medical journal has found that a common diabetes drug can significantly reduce the risk of heart failure in high-risk patients. Researchers tracked more than 10,000 participants across 20 countries over a five-year period, comparing those who received the drug to a control group on standard therapy. Patients on the medication experienced fewer hospitalizations and lower overall mortality, with benefits observed regardless of age or baseline cardiovascular health. The findings are expected to influence updated treatment guidelines for type 2 diabetes, which affects more than 400 million people worldwide. Doctors cautioned, however, that the drug is not a substitute for lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise.
per_sample.model_summary: A new study found that a commonly prescribed diabetes medication can significantly reduce the risk of heart failure in high-risk patients, with benefits observed across a five-year period. The medication, which was compared to standard therapy, resulted in fewer hospitalizations and lower overall mortality, regardless of age or baseline cardiovascular health. The findings are expected to influence updated treatment guidelines for type 2 diabetes, affecting over 400 million people worldwide.
highlights: Large trial links popular diabetes drug to reduced heart failure risk.
Patients on the medication show fewer hospitalizations and deaths.
Experts say results will shape new treatment guidelines worldwide.

per_sample.article: An ambitious urban forest project in Ahmedabad aims to plant more than 1 million trees over the next three years to combat rising temperatures and air pollution. The initiative, launched by the municipal corporation in partnership with local nonprofits, focuses on creating dense micro-forests on unused government land and along major roadways. Volunteers, including schoolchildren and corporate employees, are being trained in native-species plantation techniques inspired by the Miyawaki method. Early pilot plots have already shown faster growth rates and improved soil moisture retention, according to environmental engineers overseeing the effort. City officials hope the project will also raise public awareness about the role of green cover in mitigating the effects of climate change.

Early pilot plots have shown faster growth rates and improved soil moisture retention, with city officials hoping the project will raise public awareness about the role of green cover in mitigating climate change.

per_sample.article: In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court of a European nation has ruled that gig workers for major food-delivery apps must be classified as employees rather than independent contractors. The unanimous verdict followed years of legal challenges brought by trade unions, which argued that couriers were denied basic protections such as minimum wage, paid leave and social security benefits. The court found that the platforms exercised significant control over working hours, pricing and performance metrics, making the gig workers functionally indistinguishable from traditional staff. Industry groups warned the ruling could increase costs and lead to higher prices for consumers, while labor advocates hailed it as a victory for precarious workers. Lawmakers are now expected to draft new regulations to clarify how the decision will be implemented nationwide.
per_sample.model_summary: The Supreme Court of a European nation has ruled that gig workers for major food-delivery apps must be classified as employees, not independent contractors, due to significant control exerted by the platforms over working hours, pricing, and performance metrics. This decision could lead to increased costs and higher prices for consumers, but labor advocates hail it as a victory for precarious workers.
highlights: Top court rules food-delivery couriers are employees, not contractors.
Gig workers gain access to minimum wage, leave and social benefits.
Industry warns of higher costs as unions celebrate landmark ruling.

per_sample.article: A newly discovered exoplanet roughly 40 light-years from Earth may offer clues about how atmospheres evolve on rocky worlds, astronomers say. Using data from a space-based telescope, an international team detected traces of water vapor and carbon dioxide in the planet's thin atmosphere, despite its close orbit around a small red dwarf star. The world, slightly larger than Earth, is believed to have once hosted a thick, volatile-rich envelope that was gradually stripped away by stellar radiation. By comparing the measurements to computer simulations, scientists hope to better understand why some planets remain habitable while others become barren. The findings also demonstrate the growing power of next-generation instruments to characterize smaller, cooler exoplanets.
per_sample.model_summary: A newly discovered exoplanet, located 40 light-years from Earth, has been found to have a thin atmosphere composed of water vapor and carbon dioxide, despite being in close orbit around a small red dwarf star. This suggests that the planet's atmosphere may have evolved in a similar way to Earth's, with a thick, volatile-rich envelope that was gradually stripped away by stellar radiation. The discovery provides insights into the evolution of exoplanet atmospheres and the conditions necessary for habitability.
highlights: Scientists detect water vapor and CO2 on rocky exoplanet 40 light-years away.
Thin atmosphere suggests world was gradually stripped by stellar radiation.
Observations help explain why some planets stay habitable as others dry out.

per_sample.article: A small coastal town in Kerala has turned to community-owned solar power to shield residents from volatile electricity prices. Local authorities partnered with a cooperative bank and engineering college to install rooftop panels on schools, markets and apartment blocks, selling excess power back to the grid. Households buy shares in the cooperative, which uses revenue from electricity sales to repay loans and subsidize bills for low-income families. In just two years, the town has cut its dependence on coal-fired power plants by nearly 30 percent and reduced frequent blackouts during peak demand. The model has attracted attention from other municipalities looking for ways to decarbonize while keeping energy affordable.
per_sample.model_summary: The coastal town of Kovalam in Kerala has successfully transitioned to community-owned solar power, generating electricity from rooftop panels on schools, markets, and apartment blocks. The cooperative bank and engineering college partnered with the town to install the panels, which sell excess power back to the grid, reducing reliance on coal-fired power plants and cutting blackouts by nearly 30% in just two years. The model has attracted attention from other municipalities seeking to decarbonize while keeping energy affordable.
highlights: Kerala town builds community-owned solar network to cut power costs.
Residents buy cooperative shares and sell excess energy to the grid.
Project reduces coal reliance and blackouts while aiding poor households.

per_sample.article: International health agencies are racing to contain an outbreak of a viral respiratory illness in a densely populated megacity. Authorities have reported several hundred confirmed cases and a handful of deaths, with hospitals instructed to reserve isolation beds and expand testing. Preliminary genetic sequencing suggests the virus is related to a strain that circulated a decade ago but has since accumulated new mutations. Officials have urged people to wear masks on public transport and avoid large indoor gatherings while scientists study how easily the pathogen spreads. Neighboring countries have begun screening passengers at airports, though the World Health Organization has not yet recommended broad travel restrictions.

Authorities are urging people to wear masks on public transport and avoid large indoor gatherings to slow the spread of the pathogen.
highlights: New respiratory virus outbreak reported in crowded global megacity.

per_sample.article: An independent commission has released a scathing report on the safety practices of a national rail operator after a series of high-profile derailments. Investigators documented years of deferred maintenance, understaffing and inadequate driver training that, they say, contributed directly to preventable accidents. The report describes a culture in which employees feared retaliation for speaking up about mechanical issues or schedule pressures. In response, the transport ministry announced an immediate audit of all major lines and pledged new funding for track upgrades and signaling systems. Families of victims welcomed the findings but demanded concrete timelines, saying they had heard similar promises after previous incidents.

per_sample.article: A groundbreaking gene therapy has restored partial vision in several patients with a rare inherited retinal disease, according to results from a Phase II clinical trial. The treatment involves delivering a functional copy of a defective gene directly into eye cells using a modified viral vector. Participants, many of whom could previously only detect light and shadow, reported being able to navigate unfamiliar rooms and recognize simple objects after receiving the injection. Though the improvements varied between individuals, researchers say the outcomes exceed those seen with any prior intervention for this condition. Regulators will require larger trials to confirm safety and durability before the therapy can be considered for approval.
per_sample.model_summary: A Phase II clinical trial has successfully delivered a functional copy of a defective gene into eye cells, restoring partial vision in several patients with a rare inherited retinal disease. highlights: Experimental gene therapy helps patients with rare retinal disorder see again.

per_sample.article: A team of economists has found that offering free, high-quality school lunches can significantly narrow learning gaps between students from different income backgrounds. The study, conducted across hundreds of primary schools, compared test scores before and after the introduction of universal mid-day meals prepared to strict nutritional standards. Children in historically underperforming districts showed the largest gains, particularly in math and reading comprehension. Teachers reported improved classroom behavior and fewer afternoon absences as students were less likely to skip school. Policymakers say the findings strengthen the case for treating nutrition as a core component of education policy rather than a separate welfare program.

The findings support the case for treating nutrition as a core component of education policy rather than a separate welfare program.

Nutritionally balanced meals improve attendance and classroom behavior.
Researchers urge governments to see food as central to education policy.

per_sample.article: A coastal village in Odisha has become a living laboratory for climate adaptation as residents experiment with new crops and building techniques to withstand rising seas. Farmers are shifting from water-intensive rice to salt-tolerant millets and pulses, supported by agronomists from a nearby university. Homes damaged by repeated cyclones are being rebuilt on raised plinths, with reinforced roofs and simple rainwater harvesting systems. Local women have formed self-help groups to manage emergency savings and distribute relief supplies when storms hit. Though many families have migrated inland for work, community leaders say the changes have reduced losses from recent floods and given villagers a stronger voice in regional planning.

per_sample.article: Researchers studying urban wildlife have documented surprising levels of cooperation between different species in a sprawling Asian metropolis. Motion-triggered cameras captured footage of stray dogs, crows and monkeys foraging in close proximity at garbage dumps and markets, often timing their visits to avoid direct conflict with humans. In some neighborhoods, residents reported that dogs would bark loudly when monkeys approached open windows, inadvertently warning families to secure food and valuables. Biologists say these interactions show how animals adapt social behavior to take advantage of city resources while minimizing risk. The findings could inform new strategies for managing human–wildlife conflict without resorting to culling.

per_sample.article: A popular messaging app has rolled out a new feature that automatically blurs sensitive images by default, giving users more control over what they see. per_sample.article: A small biotechnology firm has unveiled a portable diagnostic device that can detect multiple respiratory viruses from a single drop of blood in under 15 minutes. Roughly the size of a smartphone, the unit uses microfluidic channels and fluorescent markers to identify viral signatures with high accuracy, according to early validation studies. Doctors in remote clinics could use the gadget to distinguish between infections such as influenza, COVID-19 and respiratory syncytial virus, allowing faster, more targeted treatment. The company is seeking regulatory approval and hopes to bring the device to market within two years.
